 You guys have been brain-melted all day.

especially the graph one and Evan's LSA one,

But, yeah, so my name's Justin Kohler.
I'm the product leader at Specter Ops.
That is the team over Bloodhound Enterprise
and Bloodhound Community.
What that means is I manage around 35 people,
engineers, infrastructure engineers,
customer success, support, product design,
people who I have the pleasure of representing before you,
believe in what they do.
Former Air Force, father of four.

So what we'll talk about today is attack path management,
what that means, what we've seen over the past three years,
some lessons learned, and then where do we go from here?
So what does the future hold?
So let's start with what is attack path management?
Three years ago, this guy, Andy,
wrote a attack path management manifesto
where we kind of put out this idea.
We were in this whack-a-mole game of finding attack paths,
maybe fixing some of them, maybe not,
and just this repetitive cycle that we wanted to get out of.
So could we come up with a strategy
for solving that problem once and for all?
And we had some foundational principles that we put out.
We wanted to be continuous and comprehensive,
so not reactive.
We wanted to have a very specific way we could measure risk,
so not just it's bad and believe me,
but how bad is it?
And we wanted it to be practical,
so implement least privilege.
How many times have we heard that, like how, right?
So three years ago, we came out with that,
and the industry kind of listened.
So we've seen a lot of folks pick up that message,
which is awesome, that's what we want, right?
We want people to understand that this is a problem
and that it's a problem that we can solve.
We've seen organizations like CISA say
that you shouldn't use tools to identify attack paths.
This was from a recent breach earlier this year,
where they specifically called this out,
also implement least privilege, also all that other stuff.
Gartner, last year, this is an evolution
of the vulnerability management program.
They call it now, or they're trying to call it now,
continuous threat exposure management,
and they specifically reference attack path mapping
being part of that strategy.
The way we think about it is attack path management
is really like this missing capability
within your identity risk strategy.
We've had tools like identity and access management,
privilege access management, ITDR.
These are all awesome products and awesome capabilities,
but they're not really solving the problem
that we knew about, and if you're a penetration tester,
you abuse year after year.
APM also has a really familiar process.
What does this cycle look like to anybody?
Does this look like anything?
Vulnerability management, maybe?
Very repetitive, right?
Understand what you have, prioritize it, fix it,
and then report out.
It has clear benefits, so we've seen, again,
I mentioned at the start with the principles,
but we've seen a shift over
to proactive, comprehensive visibility.
If you've ever used Bloodhound,
you know that there's thousands of paths
within most organizations,
so we can't just fix them one by one.
We're gonna be here for years,
so we have to have one fix that will sever multiple paths.
We wanted to prioritize by a measurement
that we could track back in math,
not just it's bad, but this is how bad that thing is.
And we wanted step-by-step remediation,
so not just fix the problem,
but show me where to click in the GUI,
in ADUC, in Azure, to fix it.
And measurable, meaningful progress,
so not like I have 70 issues last year,
and now I'm down to 36.
This means I had 100% exposure,
meaning 100% of people in my environment
could get to tier zero, and now I have 30.
It means something.
Attack path management, from our perspective,
will be a new standard.
Who works in an organization
that does not have a vulnerability management program?
Either you, oh, that doesn't count.
Either you do, or you're too embarrassed to raise your hand,
and I think that's gonna be the same thing with this.
Maybe not call it, who knows if it'll be called
attack path management, but this problem will be a standard.
All right, so what does three years of attack paths
look like?
So we analyzed two billion
abusable configurations and behaviors.

graphs are hard, we've experienced that problem a lot.

group policy object.

how many attack paths?
